body:
## Problem

#33575 aims to begin upstreaming configs from nvim-lspconfig. When doing this, we may experience some issues with the current merge semantics of `vim.lsp.config` with some of the complex configs. This is due to the fact the merge semantics is just the behaviour of `vim.tbl_deep_extend` and thus has no way of removing `nil` values.

Examples:
1. Core ships a config that defines `root_dir`, but the user just wants their config to use `root_markers`
2. Core ships a config with a complex `reuse_client` field, but the user wants to use the default.
3. Core ships a config with an `on_attach` field which the user does not want.

## Possible solutions

1. Use `vim.NIL` as a special value in merging to mean "delete this value"

2. Allow `lsp/*` files to return a directive (similar to treesitter query files) to define the merge semantics of that config.

   E.g. `return { ... }, 'override'`
 
3. Modify the configuration schema so every field has an explicit opt-out value (e.g. `false`)

   E.g. if a field is of type `function?` change this to `function|false?` so that function can be removed.

   #33579

comment_data.body: Solution 2 seems to me the easiest to reason about and handle in practice. (Although this doesn't rule out _also_ doing Solution 3.)

I think there is also something to be said about merging semantics of `on_attach` in order to support merging the functions in some way. If the user defines a default `on_attach` function with `vim.lsp.config("*", { on_attach = function(client, bufnr) end })` which does core work that they want to apply to all language servers, it would be nice if there was a way to do language specific setup with `vim.lsp.config(server_name, { on_attach = function(client, bufnr) end })` to do language specific `on_attach` functions.

This also shows up in the case where the user sets up a default with `"*"` and then utilizes `nvim-lspconfig` which provides LSP configuration through runtime files where some of them provide an `on_attach` function which sets up things such as useful user commands. This would promptly override what the user specified that they wanted with `"*"` which may not be the intended behavior especially when most of the language servers will work fine and only the subset that do add `on_attach` functions would behave differently.

An alternative approach would be to expect the user to rely more heavily on the `LspAttach` event to set up autocommands rather than recommending they use `on_attach` in `vim.lsp.config`. If that's the case then maybe it's good to mention that in the documentation.

>  vim.lsp.config("*", { on_attach = function(client, bufnr) end })

That's what `LspAttach` is for.

Not just `on_attach` but `on_init` and `before_init` would also be nice to have some sort of merging behavior and I don't believe those have an event you can listen to. Right now, you can do

```lua
local old_on_init = vim.lsp.config['myls'].on_init

vim.lsp.config('myls', {
  on_init = function(client)
    old_on_init(client)
    -- my additional init code
  end
})
```

but that feels quite clunky and you have to know if the base LSP config has them set.

Maybe something like providing an extra parameter `prev` which calls the existing callback / noops so users can choose whether they want to extend or replace the callback would be nice? Something like

```lua
vim.lsp.config('myls', {
  on_init = function(client, prev)
    -- inherit existing on_init, comment out to replace entirely
    prev(client)
    -- my additional init code
  end
})
```

> Core ships a config with an on_attach field which the user does not want.

Not ideal, but this particular case can be solved with empty function:
```lua
vim.lsp.config('myls', { on_attach = function() end })
```

That being said, the general problem of _"how to remove parameter from table?"_ should be solved regardless; and as I understand, it is already somewhat being tackled by #33579 (albeit I think using `false` as to-remove-flag could be disputed).

As @mehalter and @thatsmydoing notice, from the opposite end of spectrum, there's also a 2nd problem of _"how to **not** override parameter?"_. Proposition of `prev` parameter is interesting. Another approach I can think of is to have a table like so:

```lua
vim.lsp.config('myls', {
  on_attach = function() print("foo") end, -- on_attach gets overridden
  on_init = {
    queue_pos = "last",  -- our on_init will be called after pre-existing on_init function(s!)
    callback = function()
      print("bar")
    end
  },
})
```

To avoid making `vim.lsp.config` a special-case "inner platform", [extending `vim.tbl_deep_extend()`](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/33579#issuecomment-2827481259) seems like a good option. Its `behavior` arg could take a function:

```lua
vim.tbl_deep_extend(function(key, val)
  ...
end, ...)
```

Then `vim.lsp.config` can just accept that `merge` parameter and pass it along.

> As @mehalter and @thatsmydoing notice, from the opposite end of spectrum, there's also a 2nd problem of "how to not override parameter?". Proposition of prev parameter is interesting. Another approach I can think of is to have a table like so:

I think propositions like this just overcomplicate things for almost no benefit. I don't think we'll be changing the merging semantics in any significant way. We'll have to add other solutions to specific problems, or just not address them at all. Complicated server setups probably shouldn't use `vim.lsp.config` and use `vim.lsp.start` instead. We can continue to make iterative improvements if they don't overly complicate things.

Stuff like `on_attach` and other callbacks should probably be implemented as autocmds and providers should be wary about adding them.

> Stuff like `on_attach` and other callbacks should probably be implemented as autocmds and providers should be wary about adding them.

Indeed, adding events `LspInit`, `LspBeforeInit`, etc., and appropriate warnings in the docs could also be a solution.

> overcomplicate things for almost no benefit.

~~Adding a [`merge` item](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/33577#issuecomment-2832866835) to vim.lsp.config, which is passed along to `tbl_deep_extend(behavior: string|fun(key,val))`, is a complete solution, that also allows us to keep the mental model / docs simple.~~ 

Edit: rejected, see https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/33833#issuecomment-2849196557

It'll look a bit janky for users that want to do complex stuff, but will be much better than having to document "this config defines a `LspAttach` handler, delete it if you don't want it...".

We also may need this merge behavior for other things in the future, e.g. treesitter configs...

> Adding a [`merge` item](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/33577#issuecomment-2832866835) to vim.lsp.config, which is passed along to `tbl_deep_extend(behavior: string|fun(key,val))`, is a complete solution, that also allows us to keep the mental model / docs simple.

I don't disagree, but having `LspInit`, `LspBeforeInit`, etc. events would be quite useful regardless.

> having `LspInit`, `LspBeforeInit`, etc. events would be quite useful regardless

all of the surface area we add, is a new place that needs to be debugged when things go wrong. we already have start() callbacks, and if we add event handlers for all of them, then we have doubled the surface area.

open a new issue for that, it's off topic here.

I hope that isn't too late to propose this, but wouldn't it simpler and more elegant to just allow giving `vim.config()` a function (or returning one from a `lsp/*.lua` file)

This function would be given the current `rtp_config` as argument and have the following semantics:
- If it returns a table, this table is set as the new configuration.
- If it returns `nil`, it is assumed that the configuration was modified in place.

`lazy.nvim`'s `opts` key in the package spec has the same semantics, and I would say it served it well.

The implementation would probably come down to something as simple as
```lua
        elseif type(config) == 'function' then
          local res = config(rtp_config)
          if type(res) == 'nil' then
            -- Config was modified in-place
          elseif type(res) == 'table' then
            rtp_config = res
          else
            log.warn(('%s did not return either nil, or a table, ignoring'):format(v))
          end
```
at https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/2e0158650a3be0bcfdb6a2f28c6d7266c525e94a/runtime/lua/vim/lsp.lua#L443-L454

(Note that I haven't actually tested this code yet)

More sophisticated tools could then be built on top of this, while not hindering the user to build their own custom solution.
Also, by breaking the problem down to "How do I merge these two tables" in this way, tools that make it easier merge the LSP configs, could be reused in a bunch of other places as well.

@titaniumtraveler isn't that the same as https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/32287#issuecomment-2835155023 ? We seem to be aligned on that. Though https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/33833#issuecomment-2898785995 raises an interesting alternative(?):

> We probably also need to reconsider the caching of these configs. If we just remove the caching then for `lsp/` we get the same effect of allowing the config to be a function, we'd just need to pass the current config as a module argument. E.g.

> [@titaniumtraveler](https://github.com/titaniumtraveler) isn't that the same as [#32287 (comment)](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/32287#issuecomment-2835155023) ? We seem to be aligned on that. 

Pretty much. I hadn't seen that issue.
Minus the semantics of allowing both update in place **and** replacing the config.

> Though [#33833 (comment)](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/33833#issuecomment-2898785995) raises an interesting alternative(?):
> 
> > We probably also need to reconsider the caching of these configs. If we just remove the caching then for `lsp/` we get the same effect of allowing the config to be a function, we'd just need to pass the current config as a module argument. E.g.

I mean I wouldn't *really* expect users to constantly restart their LSP-Servers, so I'm not *quite* sure caching is actually useful?

The hardest part about caching is of cause *as always* to get the invalidation semantics right. But I think the solution would probably come down to "let the user register some callback that checks whether the config should be recomputed/that mutates the config if necessary".

One alternative to doing caching invalidation, though I'm not quite sure as viable it is, could be to use actual dynamic values, by using an `__index` metatable.

To still allow correct layering the configurations it would only provide "dynamic defaults":

```lua
return function(config)
    return setmetatable({ _inner }, {
        __index = function(t,k)
            if not t._inner[k] then
            -- provide dynamic value here
            end
        end,
        __newindex = function(t,k,v)
            t.inner[k] = v
       end
    })
end
```

> I mean I wouldn't _really_ expect users to constantly restart their LSP-Servers, so I'm not _quite_ sure caching is actually useful?

Without caching, wouldn't the lsp configs need to be "resolved" from the filesystem each time a new buffer is opened?

> Without caching, wouldn't the lsp configs need to be "resolved" from the filesystem each time a new buffer is opened?

Yes, though I'm not sure how bad this really is and doesn't seem any worse than `FileType` autocmds which source runtime whenever a buffer opens.

> > I mean I wouldn't _really_ expect users to constantly restart their LSP-Servers, so I'm not _quite_ sure caching is actually useful?
> 
> Without caching, wouldn't the lsp configs need to be "resolved" from the filesystem each time a new buffer is opened?

Ah, right.
Then maybe cache the values as long as the LSP-Client that is associated with that server is around? Like I wouldn't expect the configuration to change *while* the client is active.

> Then maybe cache the values as long as the LSP-Client that is associated with that server is around? Like I wouldn't expect the configuration to change while the client is active.

I'm not sure that'll work since one of the config values is `reuse_client` that detemines if the same client should be used, or create a new one.

> > Then maybe cache the values as long as the LSP-Client that is associated with that server is around? Like I wouldn't expect the configuration to change while the client is active.
> 
> I'm not sure that'll work since one of the config values is `reuse_client` that detemines if the same client should be used, or create a new one.

Maybe let the first client determine with its `reuse_client` setting whether the buffers that get started later should share the config.

I would think that having one shared LSP-Server for a lot of buffers is the common case, so it is worth to optimize for that.

[This](https://github.com/neovim/nvim-lspconfig/issues/3850#issuecomment-2901164705) reminds me that users have the option of defining `reuse_client` to set arbitrary config fields dynamically.

So I wonder how big the problem actually is here.

# Status

Both of these approaches are worth implementing IMO. Starting with the first one since it is less work and more generally useful:

1. Add a new `behavior='keepall'` to `vim.tbl_deep_extend` which more aggressively merges things. 
    - In particular, it "merges" functions by creating a closure that calls both functions, instead of just replacing the old one.
2. Allow Config to be a functions (instead of a `LspConfig` table)
    - Details [here](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/32287#issuecomment-2835155023). This will require a bit more work.
    - Eliminate `before_init`. Discussion [here](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/32287#issuecomment-2835187868).
